title: I've just discovered I'm dogshit at mid
body: I tried champions with slightly above average skillfloors but high skillcaps such as Corki, Zilean, Ziggs, Xerath etc. and fail miserably. I do not like stuff like Morgana and so I wonder, what mids would help me learn the role better? I was thinking maybe Annie since she has easy CSing with Q and more zone control than a lot of stuff I play. For example, playing Zilean vs Fizz is a nightmare because his ult.'s lower CD than mine and if he EQs me, I'm already nearly forced to ult. I just get zoned hard. This is a problem I often have. The biggest though is that when I do have lane control, I just die to ganks a lot. Annie would probably solve this since she has her E and also will generally be with the wave closer to her side. If you play Ziggs, you will naturally push, same with Zilean and Xerath. You do it for lane pressure and also because if it gets under turret, you're going to have a hard time farming. I suppose Kassadin could be an option too but I've always felt that I was not relevant fast enough in the games.

replies.body:
Ward a lot and stay near where your wards are so they cant attack from the dark side of the lane.

When your minions go up to enemy turret you don't have to follow them. If enemy shoves back you won't lose any cs and if they freeze you can roam.

As for champs to learn it, Annie, Anivia, Veigar, or Orianna should work off of the top of my head.
play annie till plat 5.  She can legit carry anyone to that elo lol.

Sure, she has some iffy matchups and no real escapes, but that's all part of the learning experience.

{{champion:4}} is also a great mid laner to learn as he has insane waveclear, and your semi-global ult can cause games to snowball.

Don't think of mid as "I have to destroy my laner", think of it as "I farm and get a good CS count for items and gank my other lanes when I can roam". 

Easiest mid is probably {{champion:90}} with his braindead ultimate surpression and spell shield passive.

Wait... Ziggs has a high skill ceiling?

> [{quoted}](name=Nik Nikerson,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=yQKxrsMq,comment-id=0005,timestamp=2017-11-19T10:47:31.184+0000)
>
> Wait... Ziggs has a high skill ceiling?

Yeah, he's all skillshots and has multiple terrain interactions. A good Ziggs also doesn't spam mindlessly. He will use E in critical areas, set up choke points and then Q your only remaining path etc.

I'm not saying he has a low skill ceiling, but he's certainly not what I'd consider a high skill ceiling champ. Outside of W interactions there's not really much to him. And don't act like learning where to put down his minefield is a difficult skill to master. It's a basic ability.

> [{quoted}](name=Nik Nikerson,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=yQKxrsMq,comment-id=000500000000,timestamp=2017-11-19T11:55:42.684+0000)
>
> I'm not saying he has a low skill ceiling, but he's certainly not what I'd consider a high skill ceiling champ. Outside of W interactions there's not really much to him. And don't act like learning where to put down his minefield is a difficult skill to master. It's a basic ability.

I disagree. He might not have amazing sexy outplays but he's all skillshots, has  a passive to manage which forces him to get closer range, has multiple terrain interactions and persistent abilities on the battlefield like EW (whose placement and choice to leave up or activate matters a lot) and he has an ult. which requires map awareness too and has multiple uses (waveclear, damage, zoning etc.). The myriad of uses for all his abilities makes him extremely high skillcap. 

He doesn't have an enormous skillfloor like that of Azir but I think he's not easier to play optimally. Even in terms of game theory, the extreme amount of potential uses for each ability should make him difficult. He's certainly a lot harder than nearly every other mid champion I can think of, including Xerath. The reason is simply the options he has, and the somewhat persistent state of all his abilities. For example, even Q you can use for the short range more likely to hit option, you can use the long range variant to zone, you can throw it just at a wall edge if you want it to bounce over etc. For most champions, they just launch an ability and that's it, there's no real need to think about it stikcing to the battlefield 10 seconds like Ziggs E or whether to choose between damage, zoning, knockback, knocktowards, etc with W. This is why his skillcap is so high, there are always so many things you could be thinking about. It's not just aiming. He has a lot more strategic depth in how he'd ideally think about and use his abilities.

With that said, I think he is terribly rewarded for his high theoretical skillcap. He's not a hypercarry like Azir and nor is he reliable like Annie. There's little reason to pick him objectively (turret taking is currently more of a snowball mechanic rather than a comp. requirement). I think the reason you don't see how high of a skillcap he has is because you are thinking of his skill floor. A relatively weak player can still be useful and the optimizations of the best Ziggs do not make an enormous difference (unlike Riven for instance). Most champions with this much theoretical complexity, will reward a player more handsomely when they think about the kit very wel. He's a bit like Ezreal in this regard. Ezreal is also a quite high skillcap champion despite not having a crazy high skill floor. Moreover, Ezreal also isn't usually sufficiently rewarded to justify picking even if you are great at him. (with the exception of this particular patch)
